In August 1992, the American film director [[Woody Allen]] was accused by his adoptive daughter Dylan Farrow, then seven years old, of having sexually assaulted her in the home of her adoptive mother, the actor [[Mia Farrow]], in [[Bridgewater, Connecticut]]. Allen has repeatedly denied the allegation.{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/woody-allen-defends-himself-on-60-minutes-in-92/|title=Woody Allen defends himself on '60 Minutes' in '92|publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate= February 8, 2018|archivedate=November 22, 2014| archiveurl=https://archive.is/VNhj0|deadurl=no}} When the allegation was made, Farrow and Allen had been in a 12-year relationship and had three children together: two adopted children, Dylan and Moses, and one biological son, Satchel (now known as [[Ronan Farrow]]). The assault is alleged to have taken place eight months after Farrow learned that Allen had been having an affair with another of her adoptive daughters, [[Soon-Yi Previn]], who married Allen in 1997; Previn was a first-year undergraduate when Farrow found out about the relationship. Allen alleges that the affair prompted Mia Farrow to concoct the assault allegation as an act of vengeance. The Connecticut [[State's Attorney]] investigated the allegation but did not press charges, and the New York Department of Social Services found "no credible evidence" to support it. In response to the allegation, Allen sued Farrow for sole custody of Dylan, Satchel and Moses. He lost the case in June 1993; the judge denied him visitation rights with Dylan, gave him limited, supervised visitation with Satchel, and allowed Moses, a teenager, to decide for himself. The decision was upheld on appeal in 1994 and 1995. Dylan Farrow has repeated the allegation several times as an adult. Her first public comment was in an interview with [[Maureen Orth]] for ''Vanity Fair'' in 2013, followed by an open letter in the ''New York Times'' in 2014, a ''Los Angeles Times'' [[op-ed]] in December 2017,. Woody Allen has also spoken publicly about the allegations, in an interview with [[Gayle King]] for ''[[CBS This Morning]]'' in a ''New York Times'' op-ed and in 2018 with a statement to CBS, denying the allegation in both.{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/woody-allen-responds-dylan-farrow-sexual-abuse-allegations/|title=Woody responds to Dylan Farrow sexual abuse allegations|date=January 18, 2018|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=8 February 2018}} ==Background== ===Allen and Farrow=== Woody Allen and Mia Farrow began a 12-year relationship in 1980, during which Farrow starred in 13 of Allen's films.{{cite news|url= https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2013/11/mia-farrow-frank-sinatra-ronan-farrow| title=Momma Mia!| first=Maureen|last=Orth|author-link=Maureen Orth|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]| date= October 23, 2013}} They maintained separate apartments in [[Manhattan]] throughout the relationship—Farrow on [[Central Park West]] and Allen on [[Fifth Avenue]]—and did not marry; they had both been married twice. [[File:Mia Farrow 2012 Shankbone.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Mia Farrow]], 2012]] When the relationship began, Farrow had seven children: three biological sons from her marriage to composer [[André Previn]]; three adopted girls (two Vietnamese and one Korean, [[Soon-Yi Previn]]); and one adopted Korean boy, Moses.{{cite news | title=Woody and Mia: A New York Story |first=Eric|last=Lax|work=The New York Times|date=February 24, 1991|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/magazine/woody-and-mia-a-new-york-story.html}}{{cite news|title=Woody Allen, Mia Farrow family tree|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/02/03/showbiz/gallery/allen-farrow-family-tree/index.html|publisher=CNN|date=May 11, 2016}} In July 1985 she adopted a baby girl, Dylan, from Texas. Allen was not involved in the adoption, but when Dylan arrived he assumed a parental role toward her and began spending more time in Farrow's home. He and Farrow went on holiday to Europe several times with the Farrow–Previn children between 1987 and 1989.{{cite news|last1=Stern|first1=Marlow|title=Inside the Shocking Custody Case Court Documents that Shed Light on the Dylan Farrow-Woody Allen Saga|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/inside-the-shocking-custody-case-court-documents-that-shed-light-on-the-dylan-farrow-woody-allen-saga|work=The Daily Beast|date=10 February 2014}} In December 1987 Farrow gave birth to Allen's biological son, Satchel (later known as [[Ronan Farrow]]).{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/arts/son-born-to-mia-farrow-and-woody-allen.html | title = Son Born to Mia Farrow And Woody Allen | agency = Associated Press |newspaper=The New York Times | date= December 22, 1987}} Farrow wanted to adopt another child in 1991; Allen said he would not take "a lousy attitude toward it" so long as she agreed to his adoption of Dylan and Moses, and in October that year she adopted another Vietnamese child.{{efn|Farrow found that the child was too disabled and needed more care than she could provide; she helped to find him another family.{{cite news|last1=Dinitia|first1=Smith|title=Picking Up The Legos And The Pieces|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/02/23/reviews/farrow-feature.html|work=The New York Times|date=May 8, 1994}}}} Allen's adoption of Dylan and Moses was finalized on December 17, 1991. {{external media | float = left | width = 230px | image1 = [https://imagesvc.timeincapp.com/v3/mm/image?url=http%3A%2F%2Fpeoplev6.alley.ws%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2016%2F08%2Fwoody-allen-01-600.jpg On holiday, Leningrad, 1987]
''Left to right'': [[Ronan Farrow|Ronan]], Lark, Woody Allen, Dylan, Fletcher, Daisy, [[Soon-Yi Previn]], Moses, and Mia Farrow. | image2 = [http://images.nymag.com/news/features/scandals/scandals120409_1992_560.jpg Allen, Farrow and Soon-Yi Previn], c. 1987. }} According to her testimony during the custody trial, Farrow became concerned about Allen's behavior around Dylan in 1987–1988. She reportedly told Allen that he was paying too much attention to Dylan and failing to give her "breathing room". He had allegedly read to Dylan while in his underwear, allowed her to suck his thumb, and would sit on her bed in the morning waiting for her to wake up. Farrow would later testify that she found Allen's relationship with Dylan at this time "relentless and overpowering" and said it had "a wooing quality". [https://www.upi.com/Archives/1993/03/25/Mia-I-worried-about-Woody-being-a-homosexual/8544733035600/ "Mia: I worried about Woody being a homosexual"]. William M. Reilly, March 25, 1993. [[UPI.com]]. Retrieved 14 October 2018. Farrow also told her therapist that she feared Woody "would abuse Satchel", and that she also worried that Allen had a sexual relationship "with another man". On one occasion, Dylan allegedly locked herself in the bathroom for four hours when he arrived; Allen had an employee pick the lock with a coat hanger. The family psychologist, Dr. Susan Coates, witnessed some of Allen's behavior and testified during the custody trial in 1993 that she did not see it as sexual, but as "inappropriately intense because it excluded everybody else". Allen said later that he had paid extra attention to Dylan to compensate for the time Farrow was spending with the newborn, Satchel. He agreed in 1990 to discuss the issue in therapy sessions. ===Relationship with Previn=== In or around 1991 Allen began an affair with Farrow's adopted daughter Soon-Yi Previn. According to Allen, it began in late December 1991. According to Farrow, it began while Previn was in her final year of high school, which ended in June 1991. She alleges that Dylan saw Allen and Previn on the bed together in the summer or autumn of 1991.{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Farrow Says Daughter Became Distraught Over Allen's Relentless Attention|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/02/23/reviews/farrow-trial.html|work=The New York Times|date=March 27, 1993}} One of the bones of contention has been how old Previn was at the time. When Farrow and André Previn adopted her from [[Seoul]] in 1978, the Seoul family court gave her a "presumptive birth date" of October 8, 1970; she had been abandoned and was living in that city's St. Paul's Orphanage.{{efn|"Information concerning this case was obtained from Mr. and Mrs. André G. Previn ... The beneficiary, Soon Hee Oh, aka Soon Yi Oh, is a native and citizen of Korea with a presumptive birth date of October 8, 1970."United States Congressional Serial Set, Issue 13173, 1977, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1TYoAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Soon+Hee+Oh,+aka+Soon+Yi+Oh%22 170]. "Memorandum of information concerning H.R. 1352 for the relief of Oh Soon Hee submitted by the American Embassy at Seoul, Korea. The beneficiary is an abandoned child, who was found in Seoul, Korea on February 12, 1976. She was placed temporarily in the care of Maria's House, a local institution for abandoned children while an effort was made to identify and locate her parents and relatives. When this search failed, the beneficiary was transferred to the care of St. Paul's Orphanage ... in Seoul, where she currently lives. The Seoul Family Court established a Family Census Register (legal birth document) in her behalf on December 28, 1976, with a presumptive birth date of October 8, 1970. The beneficiary attends kindergarten classes held in the orphanage. Through the auspices of the Social Welfare Society, Inc., ... and the Friends of Children adoption agency in the United States, the child has been selected for adoption by Mr. and Mrs. André George Previn, of Martha's Vineyard, Mass. ...United States Congressional Serial Set, 1978, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UPBIAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Soon-Yi%22+Previn+%22October+8%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22October+8%22 cxlii–cxliv].}} A bone scan in the United States in 1978 indicated that she was between five and seven years old; according to Farrow, the family regarded her date of birth as October 8, 1972. The timing of the affair became an issue in part because Farrow attempted, unsuccessfully, to have Allen's adoption of Dylan and Moses declared void after the molestation allegation, on the grounds that his affair with Previn had begun before the adoptions were finalized on December 17, 1991. [[File:Soon Yi Previn and Woody Allen at the Tribeca Film Festival.jpg|thumb|left|[[Soon-Yi Previn]] and [[Woody Allen]], 2009]] During her final year of high school, Previn told Allen that she wanted to be a model; he advised her how to dress and arranged for professional photographs to be taken. She reportedly asked if she could accompany him to a basketball game, and after attending several together, they became closer.{{cite news|last1=Isaacson|first1=Walter|title=The Heart Wants What It Wants|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,160439,00.html|work=Time|date=June 24, 2001|at=First published August 31, 1992}} Their affair came to light on January 13, 1992, when Farrow found nude [[Instant camera|Polaroid]] photographs of Previn on the [[Fireplace mantel|mantel]] in Allen's home. Previn was by then in her first year at [[Drew University]] in New Jersey. Allen, then 56, told Farrow that he had taken the photographs the day before, and that he and Previn had first had sex in the last week of December 1991.{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Nude Photographs Are Focus Of Woody Allen's Testimony|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/23/nyregion/nude-photographs-are-focus-of-woody-allen-s-testimony.html|work=The New York Times|date=March 23, 1993}} Allen told the custody trial in 1993 that he regarded the images as erotic, but not pornographic; the appellate court said that it did not "share Mr. Allen's characterization" of the photographs. Although the discovery shocked the family, Farrow did not stop Allen from visiting her home, and she completed her work on ''[[Husbands and Wives]]'' (1992), the last film of his in which she appeared.{{cite news|last1=Grimes|first1=William|title=A Chronology of a Film's Making And a Relationship's Unmaking|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/31/movies/a-chronology-of-a-film-s-making-and-a-relationship-s-unmaking.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 31, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=James|title=Plot of New Woody Allen Film Seems to Mimic His Life|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/21/nyregion/plot-of-new-woody-allen-film-seems-to-mimic-his-life.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 21, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=James|first1=Caryn|title=Film View; And Here We Thought We Knew Him|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/09/06/movies/film-view-and-here-we-thought-we-knew-him.html|work=The New York Times|date=September 6, 1992}} According to Farrow, Allen said his relationship with Previn was over; she alleged that Allen asked her to issue a joint press release, in response to rumors about the relationship, in which she would confirm there was nothing between Allen and Previn, but she refused to do it.{{cite book|last1=Farrow|first1=Mia|title=What Falls Away|date=1997|publisher=Bantam|location=New York|page=269|ref=harv}} She was hurt and angry; in February she sent Allen a [[Valentine card]] with [[skewer]]s through the hearts of the children and a knife through hers. She nevertheless adopted two more children that month: Tam, a blind Vietnamese girl, and Isaiah Justus, an African-American baby boy. Allen and Previn remained in contact; in July 1992 she lost her job as a summer-camp counselor in Maine after spending too much time on the telephone with a "Mr. Simon", who turned out to be Allen. In July 1992, after Allen visited Connecticut to celebrate Dylan's birthday, Farrow left a note near Allen's bedroom, in which she called him a "child molester." "Allen Said Farrow Made Good On Her Promise". [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19921123&id=orwzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PPADAAAAIBAJ&pg=1660,2745737&hl=en] ''[[The Spokesman-Review]]'', November 23rd, 1992. (p.1) Retrieved 14 October 2018. On 1 August 1992, according to the testimony of Dr. Susan Coates, Farrow telephoned Dr. Coates to say she had learned that Previn and Allen were still in a relationship; Farrow was distressed and told Coates that, just a week earlier, she and Allen had talked about getting married. Allen publicly announced his relationship with Previn on August 17th, 1992. As Allen and Mia Farrow had never gotten married, and as Allen had never adopted Soon-Yi, their relationship was not illegal. [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/137176042?searchTerm=jack%20waterford%20%22soon-yi%22%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits= "Modern Reasons For Old Taboos on Incest".] Jack Waterford, ''[[The Canberra Times]]''. 27 August 1992 (p 9) Retrieved 14th October 2018. Previn and Allen's relationship did continue, and they were married in Venice on December 23, 1997.{{cite news|last1=Collins|first1=Glenn|title=Mixed Reviews Greet Woody Allen Marriage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/nyregion/mixed-reviews-greet-woody-allen-marriage.html|work=The New York Times|date=December 25, 1997}} ==Allegation== On August 4, 1992, Allen visited his children at Farrow's country home in Bridgewater, Connecticut, while Farrow and a friend went shopping with the two most recently adopted children, Tam and Isaiah. Farrow and Allen had been due on August 6 to sign an agreement that Allen would pay $6,000 a month for the support of Dylan, Satchel and Moses. Present in the house, once Farrow had left, were Dylan and Satchel; Farrow's babysitter, Kristie Groteke; the children's French tutor, Sophie Berge; Farrow's friend's three children; and Farrow's friend's babysitter, Alison Stickland.{{sfnp|Farrow|1997|p=270}} The day after the visit, Stickland told her employer that she had seen Allen kneel on the floor in front of Dylan, then aged seven, with his face in her lap turned toward Dylan's body; she testified to that effect during the custody trial.{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Sitter Questions Allen Actions With Daughter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/04/10/nyregion/sitter-questions-allen-actions-with-daughter.html|work=The New York Times|date=April 10, 1993}} When Farrow asked Dylan about it, Dylan described what had happened and said she had not liked it; she also said that Allen had touched her "private part" while they were alone together in the attic crawl space.{{cite news |last=Orth|first=Maureen|author-link=Maureen Orth|title=Mia's Story|magazine=Vanity Fair|date=August 5, 2008|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/archive/1992/11/farrow199211|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221205817/http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/archive/1992/11/farrow199211|archive-date=November 1992|deadurl=no}} Farrow made a videotape of Dylan repeating the allegation, which she said was filmed "in fits and starts" over the following 24 hours,{{harvnb|Farrow|1997|p=272}}; {{cite news|title=Woody Allen claims videotape proves Mia's 'unfitness' as mother|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/12/21/Woody-Allen-claims-videotape-proves-Mias-unfitness-as-mother/4450724914000/|publisher=UPI|date=December 21, 1992}} and telephoned her lawyer, who told her to take Dylan to a doctor. Farrow took Dylan to Dr. Vadakkekara Kavirajan, the regular paediatrician for Farrow's children. Dylan did not repeat the allegation to the paediatrician that day, but she did the following day during a second visit; Dr. Kavirajan then informed authorities, The doctor found no physical evidence of sexual assault.{{sfnp|Farrow|1997|p=272}}{{cite web|last1=Orth|first1=Maureen|title=10 Undeniable Facts About the Woody Allen Sexual-Abuse Allegation|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2014/02/woody-allen-sex-abuse-10-facts|website=Vanity Fair|date=7 February 2014}}[https://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/08/19/Woody-Abuse-charge-video-tape-forced-him-to-seek-childrens-custody/5213714196800/ "Woody: Abuse charge, video tape forced him to seek children's custody"] Frederick M Winship. August 19th, 1992. UPI. Retrieved 14 October 2018. Dr. Kavirajan would later tell an interviewer that he was "required by state law" to report any allegations of child abuse. Dr. Susan Coates informed Allen of the allegation during a therapy session; he responded "I'm completely flabbergasted," repeating it several times. ==Legal action== ===Custody proceedings, statements=== On August 13, 1992, a week after being told about the allegation, Allen began proceedings in [[New York Supreme Court]] for sole custody of Dylan, Moses, and his and Farrow's biological son, Satchel.{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Bruce|title=Woody Allen Files Child-Custody Lawsuit|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/14/nyregion/woody-allen-files-child-custody-lawsuit.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 14, 1992}} Farrow's mother, the actor [[Maureen O'Sullivan]], issued a statement on August 15 that was critical of Allen and said that Farrow had retained [[Alan Dershowitz]].{{cite news|last1=Rabinovitz|first1=Jonathan|title=War! Mia Fights Back With (Gasp!) Publicity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/16/nyregion/war-mia-fights-back-with-gasp-publicity.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 16, 1992}} Two days later, Allen released his first public comment about his relationship with Soon-Yi Previn: "Regarding my love for Soon-Yi: It's real and happily all true. She's a lovely, intelligent, sensitive woman who has and continues to turn around my life in a wonderfully positive way."{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Bruce|title=Public Disclosures From the Private Life of Woody Allen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/18/nyregion/public-disclosures-from-the-private-life-of-woody-allen.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 18, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Alissa|title=Why Woody Allen hasn't been toppled by the #MeToo reckoning — yet|url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2018/1/11/16635446/woody-allen-dylan-farrow-mia-ronan-sexual-assault-allegation-metoo|work=Vox|date=January 11, 2018}} On August 18 Allen held a news conference at the [[Plaza Hotel]]. Calling the molestation allegation "an unconscionable and gruesomely damaging manipulation of innocent children for vindictive and self-serving motives", he alleged that, during a meeting on August 3, Farrow's lawyers had demanded $5–8 million.{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Dershowitz Says Farrow Involved Him|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/04/16/nyregion/dershowitz-says-farrow-involved-him.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 16, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=James|title=Striking Back, Woody Allen Denies Child Sex-Abuse Allegation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/19/nyregion/striking-back-woody-allen-denies-child-sex-abuse-allegation.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 19, 1992}} Dershowitz responded that the lawyers had suggested Allen pay a lump sum in child support, rather than a monthly one, to reduce Allen's interaction with Farrow.{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=James|title=Allen 'Spoiled and Mutilated' His Better Self, Farrow Says|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/20/nyregion/allen-spoiled-and-mutilated-his-better-self-farrow-says.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 20, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Goldman|first1=John J.|title=Final Arguments in Allen Custody Trial as Bitter as First|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-05-05/news/mn-31539_1_daughter-farrow|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 5, 1993}} On August 20 Allen's publicist announced that Allen had passed a lie detector test. The following day, Allen gave an interview to [[Walter Isaacson]] of ''Time'' magazine, describing the nude photographs of Previn as a "lark of a moment". Of the affair, he said: "I didn't feel that just because she was Mia's daughter, there was any great moral dilemma. It was a fact, but not one with any great import."{{cite news|last1=Hevesi|first1=Dennis|title=Woody Allen Tells His Side to a Magazine|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/23/nyregion/woody-allen-tells-his-side-to-a-magazine.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 23, 1992}} ===Yale–New Haven Hospital team=== On August 17 the [[Connecticut State Police]] announced that they were investigating the assault allegation.{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Bruce|title=Public Disclosures From the Private Life of Woody Allen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/18/nyregion/public-disclosures-from-the-private-life-of-woody-allen.html|work=The New York Times|date=August 18, 1992}} Frank Maco, the Connecticut State's Attorney for the Litchfield district, asked the Child Sexual Abuse Clinic of [[Yale–New Haven Hospital]] to evaluate whether Dylan would make a viable witness. Consisting of two social workers, a nurse and Dr. John M. Leventhal, a pediatrician, the Yale–New Haven team interviewed Dylan, Dylan's psychologist, Allen, Farrow, their domestic staff, and others.{{cite news|last1=Winter|first1=Jessica|title=Woody Allen and Dylan Farrow: Just the Facts|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/culturebox/2014/02/woody_allen_and_dylan_farrow_digging_deeper_into_misleading_coverage.html|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=February 7, 2014}} Leventhal signed the team's report, while Dylan was interviewed by the social workers. Completed in March 1993, the report went beyond its brief, concluding: "It is our expert opinion that Dylan was not sexually abused by Mr. Allen".{{efn|[[Yale–New Haven Hospital]] Child Sexual Abuse Clinic (1993): "It is our expert opinion that Dylan was not sexually abused by Mr. Allen. Further, we believe that Dylan’s statements on videotape and her statements to us during our evaluation do not refer to actual events that occurred to her on August 4th, 1992 ... In developing our opinion we considered three hypotheses to explain Dylan's statements. First, that Dylan’s statements were true and that Mr. Allen had sexually abused her; second, that Dylan’s statements were not true but were made up by an emotionally vulnerable child who was caught up in a disturbed family and who was responding to the stresses in the family; and third, that Dylan was coached or influenced by her mother, Ms. Farrow. While we can conclude that Dylan was not sexually abused, we can not be definite about whether the second formulation by itself or the third formulation by itself is true. We believe that it is more likely that a combination of these two formulations best explains Dylan’s allegations of sexual abuse."}} Its conclusion was based, in part, on the view that Dylan had difficulty telling a consistent story and suffered from "thought disturbances".{{cite book|last1=Ewing|first1=Charles Patrick||author1-link=Charles Patrick Ewing|last2=McCann|first2=Joseph T.|title=Minds on Trial: Great Cases in Law and Psychology|date=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|at=(pp. 153–164), p. 159|chapter=Woody Allen and Mia Farrow: A Swing of King Solomon's Sword|ref=harv}}{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Woody Allen Says Report Clears Him|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/19/nyregion/woody-allen-says-report-clears-him.html|work=The New York Times|date=March 19, 1993}}{{efn|[[Maureen Orth]] (''Vanity Fair'', February 7, 2014): "The report concluded Dylan had trouble distinguishing fantasy from reality. (For example, she had told them there were 'dead heads' in the attic and called sunset 'the magic hour.' In fact, Mia kept wigs from her movies on styrofoam blocks in a trunk in the attic.) The doctor subsequently backed down from his contention."}} The team destroyed its notes for reasons that were never explained.{{sfnp|Ewing|McCann|2006|p=160}} It passed its report directly to Allen and Farrow, rather than giving it to Maco, who had requested it. Maco told a reporter in 1997 that Yale "took the case and ran away with it". ===Custody trial=== ====Testimony==== The custody hearings began on March 19, 1993, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan,{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Woody Allen Tells of Affair as Custody Battle Begins|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/20/nyregion/woody-allen-tells-of-affair-as-custody-battle-begins.html|work=The New York Times|date=March 20, 1993}} and ended on May 4.{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Allen-Farrow Trial Ends in New Round of Old Charges|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/05/05/nyregion/allen-farrow-trial-ends-in-new-round-of-old-charges.html|work=The New York Times|date=May 5, 1993}} Journalists were allowed in court but not with television cameras or microphones.{{cite news|last1=Penez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Judge Bars Broadcasters From Farrow-Allen Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/12/nyregion/judge-bars-broadcasters-from-farrow-allen-case.html|work=The New York Times|date=December 12, 1992}} Taking the stand on the first day, Allen said the allegation was Farrow's vengeance for his affair with Soon Yi-Previn, which he had not intended to be "anything but a private thing"; he had hoped Farrow would not find out about it. He described her anger when she did. [[File:NYC - New York County Supreme Courthouse.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|New York State Supreme Courthouse]] Kristie Groteke,{{cite book|last1=Groteke|first1=Kristie|last2=Rosen|first2=Marjorie|title=Mia & Woody: Love and Betrayal|date=1994|publisher=Carroll & Graf Publishers|location=New York}} Farrow's babysitter, testified in April that for about 15–20 minutes on the afternoon in question, she had not been able to find Dylan or Allen in the house; she had assumed they were outside with the other children. Allen said he had gone to the bathroom during the disputed period. The children's French tutor, Sophie Berge, testified that she had noticed Dylan had been wearing no underwear under her dress that day.{{cite news|last1=Wypijewski|first1=Joann|title=Woody and Mia: A Modern Family Timeline|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/woody-and-mia-modern-family-timeline/|work=The Nation|date=February 26, 2014}} Another Farrow-household nanny, Monica Thompson, who was not present in the house on that day, told Allen's lawyers in two [[affidavit]]s in February 1993 that she had felt pressured by Farrow to support the allegation.{{cite news|last1=Span|first1=Paula|title=Clash of the Nannies|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1993/04/07/clash-of-the-nannies/97418ba8-5206-4a36-888f-ce1d54b3f84f|work=The Washington Post|date=April 7, 1993}} Thompson said that Groteke had also had reservations; according to Thompson, Groteke told her, days after the allegation was made, that she "did not have Dylan out of her sight for longer than five minutes. She did not remember Dylan being without her underwear."{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-02-02/news/mn-952_1_woody-allen|title=Nanny Casts Doubt on Farrow Charges|date=February 2, 1993|first=John J.|last=Goldman|work=Los Angeles Times|archivedate=January 19, 2018| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180119042801/http://articles.latimes.com/1993-02-02/news/mn-952_1_woody-allen|deadurl=no}} Dr. Susan Coates, a Farrow family therapist, testified that Farrow had been so angry with Allen when she discovered the affair with Previn that Coates had feared for Allen's safety.{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Doctor Recounts Threats By Farrow Against Allen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/02/23/reviews/farrow-doctor.html|work=The New York Times|date=March 30, 1993}} Farrow's lawyer accused Coates of gullibility for having accepted Allen's version of events.{{cite news|last1=Grimes|first1=William|title=Farrow's Lawyer Takes Aim at Doctor's Judgment|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/31/nyregion/farrow-s-lawyer-takes-aim-at-doctor-s-judgment.html|work=The New York Times|date=March 31, 1993}} One of Allen's lawyers alleged that Farrow's lawyers had suggested "the charges could be made to go away" if Allen agreed to pay around $7 million. Alan Dershowitz, representing Farrow, said there had been an "exploratory" session to attempt mediation. "To have this described as an extortionate meeting is ridiculous," he said. He added that Allen's lawyers were "trying to set a trap, the trap failed and now they testify as if the trap succeeded". One of Allen's lawyers acknowledged when cross-examined that the discussion about money related mostly to the children's education and medical care, as well as money owed for Farrow's film work for Allen. Dr. John Leventhal of the Yale–New Haven Child Sexual Abuse Clinic testified by [[Deposition (law)|deposition]] on 20 April. Citing inconsistencies in Dylan's account, he said the Yale–New Haven team "had two hypotheses: one, that these were statements that were made by an emotionally disturbed child and then became fixed in her mind. And the other hypothesis was that she was coached or influenced by her mother. We did not come to a firm conclusion. We think that it was probably a combination."{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Doctor Cites Inconsistencies In Dylan Farrow's Statements|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/05/04/nyregion/doctor-cites-inconsistencies-in-dylan-farrow-s-statements.html|work=The New York Times|date=May 4, 1993}} Farrow and Allen both hired experts to discuss the report. Dr. Anne Meltzer, a forensic psychologist, testified for Allen that the report had "reached conclusions that were supported well by the data they collected." She said the tape of Dylan making the allegation was "flawed" because it had been filmed by one side and not by a professional.{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Tracey L.|title=Judge in Woody-Mia child custody case airs anti-Allen views|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1993/04/26/Judge-in-Woody-Mia-child-custody-case-airs-anti-Allen-views/5124735796800/|publisher=UPI|date=April 26, 1993}} Dr. Stephen Harman, a child psychiatrist, testified for Farrow that the report was "seriously flawed", and that he could find no evidence of a thought disorder in Dylan's statements.{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Yale Study About Allen Flawed, Expert Testifies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/04/28/nyregion/yale-study-about-allen-flawed-expert-testifies.html|work=The New York Times|date=April 28, 1993}} According to [[Charles Patrick Ewing]] and Joseph McCann, the most damaging criticism of the report was that the team had destroyed its notes from the interviews it conducted, which meant the court could not test the validity of the report's conclusions; they write that forensic experts have an obligation to retain their notes for review. Another criticism was that the team was unwilling to testify in court, except via Leventhal's deposition.{{sfnp|Ewing|McCann|2006|p=160}} ====Decision==== In his 33-page decision in June 1993, Justice Elliott Wilk rejected Allen's bid for custody of the three children, and denied Allen immediate visitation rights with Dylan, saying of Allen's behavior toward Dylan that it was "grossly inappropriate and that measures must be taken to protect her".{{sfnp|Ewing|McCann|2006|p=161}} His criticism of Allen's parenting was harsh.{{sfnp|Ewing|McCann|2006|pp=160–161}} Rejecting Allen's portrayal of Farrow as a "woman scorned", Wilk said there was no credible evidence that she had coached Dylan, and he criticized Allen for his "trial strategy" of turning family members and employees against one another. The Yale–New Haven team's unwillingness to testify in court, except through Leventhal's deposition, together with the destruction of its notes, had rendered its report, he wrote, "sanitized and, therefore, less credible".{{sfnp|Ewing|McCann|2006|p=160}}{{cite news|last1=Shea|first1=Danny|title=Here’s The 1993 Woody Allen Custody Ruling In Its Damning, Detailed Entirety|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/danny-shea/heres-the-1993-woody-alle_b_4746866.html|work=HuffPost|date=February 7, 2014}}; {{cite court | litigants = Allen v. Farrow (1993) | court = N.Y. Sup. | date = June 7, 1993 }}{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Peter|title=Allen Loses to Farrow in Bitter Custody Battle|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/02/23/reviews/farrow-verdict.html|work=The New York Times|date=June 8, 1993}} Wilk called the case "frivolous" and ordered Allen to pay Farrow's costs.{{sfnp|Ewing|McCann|2006|p=161}} ===Criminal inquiry, social services=== The police interviewed Allen in Litchfield in January 1993 for over three hours. He said he had never been in the attic crawl space; when the police said they had taken fingerprints in there, he said it was possible that his prints were there. On September 20 that year, Frank Maco, the State's Attorney, accompanied by a female police detective, talked to Dylan; Maco told a reporter in 1997: "I saw complete withdrawal any time I tried to discuss the incident." On September 24, 1993, Maco held a news conference to say that he would not pursue the molestation allegation, despite having [[probable cause]], citing a desire not to traumatize Dylan.{{cite news|last1=Thibault|first1=Andy|title=People: Frank Maco|url=http://www.connecticutmag.com/the-connecticut-story/mia-farrow-s-vanity-fair-interview-references-connecticut-magazine-article/article_4327cac7-ffef-5eb5-9c19-fdaf70e84855.html|work=Connecticut Magazine|date=November 1997}}{{cite news |first=Melinda|last=Henneberger|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/25/nyregion/connecticut-prosecutor-won-t-file-charges-against-woody-allen.html | title = Connecticut Prosecutor Won't File Charges Against Woody Allen | work = The New York Times | date = September 25, 1993}}{{cite news|title=Dylan Farrow details her sexual assault allegations against Woody Allen|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/dylan-farrow-interview-today-gayle-king-full-transcript-woody-allen-me-too/|publisher=CBS News|date=January 18, 2018}}In a letter to the New York Department of Social Sevices, Allen's psychotherapist Kathryn Prescott stated that Allen's psychological profile "was definitely not that of a sexual offender" and also stated “There has never been any suggestion that Mr. Allen was suffering from a sexual perversion / deviant sexual behavior”. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1241&dat=19930421&id=Y35TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FIYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6340,6035301&hl=en "Therapist says Woody Allen No Sex Offender"]. Jeanne King, ''[[Daily News (Kingsport)|Daily News]]'', (p.12) April 21st, 1993. Retrieved 14 October 2018. The New York Department of Social Services closed its own 14-month investigation in October 1993; its letter to Allen stated: "No credible evidence was found that the child named in this report has been abused or maltreated. This report has, therefore, been considered unfounded."{{cite news|last1=Pérez-Peña|first1=Richard|title=Agency Drops Abuse Inquiry in Allen Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/26/nyregion/agency-drops-abuse-inquiry-in-allen-case.html|work=The New York Times|date=October 26, 1993}} Allen filed complaints with the Connecticut Criminal Justice Commission and the statewide bar counsel over Maco's statement about probable cause.{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Woody Allen Asks Connecticut to Discipline Prosecutor|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/14/nyregion/woody-allen-asks-connecticut-to-discipline-prosecutor.html|work=The New York Times|date=October 14, 1993}} The former dismissed the complaint in November 1993.{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Randy|title=Woody Allen Fails to Beat A Prosecutor|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/04/nyregion/woody-allen-fails-to-beat-a-prosecutor.html|work=The New York Times|date=November 4, 1993}} In February 1994 the statewide Grievance Committee ruled that, while Maco had not violated the state's code of conduct for lawyers, his statement was a cause of "grave concern". In addition, Maco had sent a copy of his statement to the judge who was deciding whether to overturn Allen's adoption of Dylan and Moses. That act was "inappropriate, unsolicited and potentially prejudicial", the panel ruled.{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Panel Criticizes Prosecutor In Inquiry on Woody Allen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/24/nyregion/panel-criticizes-prosecutor-in-inquiry-on-woody-allen.html|work=The New York Times|date=February 24, 1994}} ===Allen's appeals, other legal action=== In December 1992 Farrow began legal action, which was ultimately unsuccessful, to have Allen's adoption of Dylan and Moses declared void. Her position was based, in part, on her view that Allen's affair with Soon-Yi Previn had begun before the adoption was finalized on December 17, 1991.{{cite news|last1=Perez-Pena|first1=Richard|title=Farrow Spurns Allen's Plea For a Truce|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/10/nyregion/farrow-spurns-allen-s-plea-for-a-truce.html|work=The New York Times|date=June 19, 1993}} Allen stated that the sexual relationship had started in the last week of 1991. Allen offered not to appeal the custody ruling if Farrow would drop her attempt to have his adoption of Dylan and Moses declared void, but she refused. In January 1994 Allen appealed Wilk's decision.{{cite news|last1=Perez Pena|first1=Richard|title=Woody Allen Appeals Judgment in Custody Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/14/nyregion/woody-allen-appeals-judgment-in-custody-case.html|work=The New York Times|date=January 14, 1994}} Of the assault allegation, the appellate court stated that its "review of the record militates against a finding that Ms. Farrow fabricated the allegations without any basis". Although the Yale–New Haven team's view that Dylan had a tendency to "withdraw into a fantasy", and that she had offered inconsistent accounts, had to be taken into account, the court stated that "the testimony given at trial by the individuals caring for the children that day, the videotape of Dylan made by Ms. Farrow the following day and the accounts of Dylan's behavior toward Mr. Allen both before and after the alleged instance of abuse, suggest that the abuse did occur." It added that "the evidence in support of the allegations remains inconclusive". The court was critical of Allen's parenting skills and relationship with Soon-Yi Previn. The appeal failed, although two of the five judges said the visitation rights regarding Satchel were too restrictive.[https://www.leagle.com/decision/1994524197ad2d3271461 Allen v. Farrow (1994)] (Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, First Department, May 12, 1994). Allen appealed again, and in July 1995 the [[New York Court of Appeals]] upheld the original decision.[https://www.leagle.com/decision/1995352215ad2d1371310 Allen v. Farrow (1995)] (Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, First Department, May 4, 1995).{{pb}} {{cite news|last1=Brozan|first1=Nadine|title=Chronicle|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/06/style/chronicle-460695.html|work=The New York Times|date=July 6, 1995}} ==Later statements, reception== ===''What Falls Away''=== In her 1997 memoir, ''What Falls Away'', Farrow repeated the accusation that Allen had sexually abused Dylan Farrow.{{cite book|last1=Farrow|first1=Mia|title=What Falls Away|date=1997|publisher=Bantam|location=New York|page=271|ref=harv}} Farrow's abuse allegation was mentioned in several of the book's reviews. " Ms. Farrow claimed that Mr. Allen had long been focusing inappropriate sexual attention on their 7-year-old adoptive daughter Dylan."[https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/books/98/02/01/bsp/25818.html]"Intimate Strangers". [[Kathryn Harrison]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' 23rd February, 1997. Retrieved 14th October, 2018. "In Farrow's life, apparently, no gruesome situation goes untopped: She further claims that Allen was guilty of sexually abusing her 7-year-old adopted daughter." [http://articles.latimes.com/1997-03-02/books/bk-33844_1_mia-farrow "Rosemary's Mother".] Celia McGee, ''[[LA Times]], March 2nd, 1997. Retrieved October 14th, 2018. ===Siblings, open letter=== [[File:Ronan Farrow, Ukraine, 23 March 2012 (cropped) .jpg|thumb|left|[[Ronan Farrow]], 2012]] When Allen won the [[Golden Globe Cecil B. DeMille Award]] in January 2014, Mia Farrow and Satchel (now the journalist [[Ronan Farrow]]) tweeted objections.{{cite news|last1=Pulver|first1=Andrew|title=Woody Allen Golden Globe greeted with derision by Mia and Ronan Farrow|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jan/13/golden-globes-woody-allen-mia-farrow-tweet|work=The Guardian|date=January 13, 2014}} Dylan Farrow, by then 28, repeated the assault allegation the following month in an open letter in ''The New York Times'' blog of [[Nicholas Kristof]], a family friend. Writing that Allen had made her feel uncomfortable "for as long as [she] could remember", she alleged, for example, that he would get into bed with her in his underwear and that she would hide to avoid him.{{cite news|first=Dylan|last=Farrow|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/02/opinion/sunday/kristof-dylan-farrows-story.html |title=Dylan Farrow's Story |work=The New York Times |date=February 1, 2014}} Allen called the allegations "untrue and disgraceful",{{cite news|title=Woody Allen Calls Sexual Abuse Claims 'Untrue and Disgraceful'|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/woody-allen-calls-sexual-abuse-claims-untrue-and-disgraceful-1201083173/|work=Variety|date=February 2, 2014}} and responded with an op-ed in ''The New York Times''.{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=Woody|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/09/opinion/sunday/woody-allen-speaks-out.html|title=Woody Allen Speaks Out|work=The New York Times|date=February 7, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Thibault|first1=Andy|title=Cool Justice: New York Times bent rules for Woody Allen, but not for Frank Maco|url=http://www.nhregister.com/columns/article/Cool-Justice-New-York-Times-bent-rules-for-Woody-11384930.php|work=New Haven Register|date=February 14, 2014}} The newspaper allowed Dylan's open letter 936 words within Kristof's blog, Ronan wrote, while Allen's op-ed was given twice the length and published in the print edition. Ronan, aged four in 1992, has been critical of Allen for several years; in 2011 he tweeted: "He's my father married to my sister. That makes me his son and his brother-in-law. That is such a moral transgression."{{cite news|last1=Ullman|first1=Joan|title=Ronan Farrow: Man on a Mission|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/uncharted-customs/201801/ronan-farrow-man-mission|work=Psychology Today|date=January 3, 2018}} In ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' in May 2016, he wrote that, following the publication of Dylan's open letter, his colleagues had forwarded him the daily emails "blasted out by Allen's powerful publicist", with an open [[Carbon copy|cc list]], offering talking points for reporters and the names of friends, therapists and lawyers willing to be interviewed. He wrote: "Reporters on the receiving end of this kind of PR blitz have to wonder if deviating from the talking points might jeopardize their access to all the other A-list clients."{{Cite news|first=Ronan|last=Farrow|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/my-father-woody-allen-danger-892572|title=My Father, Woody Allen, and the Danger of Questions Unasked (Guest Column)|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date= May 11, 2016}} Dylan's brother Moses Farrow, who was 14 in 1992, has taken a different view; he has reconciled with Allen and is now estranged from the Farrow family. When Dylan published her open letter, he said in an interview that several people had been in the house on the disputed day and that "no one, not my father or sister, was off in any private spaces". He asserted that Mia Farrow had cultivated a climate in which he and his siblings had felt compelled to support her views, and that she had both physically and emotionally abused him.{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Rothman|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/dylan-farrows-brother-moses-mia-farrow-woody-allen/story?id=22377303|title=Dylan Farrow's Brother Moses Says Mia Farrow, Not Woody Allen Was Abusive |publisher= ABC News |date= February 5, 2014}}{{pb}} {{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Pulver|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/feb/05/woody-allen-dylan-farrow-moses|title=Moses Farrow defends Woody Allen over child abuse allegations |date=5 February 2013|work= The Guardian}} He repeated the allegations in 2017 to [[Eric Lax]], one of Allen's biographers.{{cite book|first=Eric|last=Lax|author-link=Eric Lax|url=|title=Start To Finish: Woody Allen and the Art of MovieMaking |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location=New York|date=2017|pp=123–129}} Moses Farrow offered additional details defending Allen in a May 23, 2018, a blog post.{{cite web|url=https://mosesfarrow.blogspot.nl/2018/05/a-son-speaks-out-by-moses-farrow.html|title=A Son Speaks Out |first=Moses |last=Farrow |publisher=Moses Farrow official blog|date=May 23, 2018|accessdate=May 26, 2018|archivedate=May 26, 2018|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180526025527/http://mosesfarrow.blogspot.com/2018/05/a-son-speaks-out-by-moses-farrow.html|deadurl=no}} In that letter he accused [[Mia Farrow]] of child abuse and neglect, coupled with a [[white savior]] complex: "When Soon-Yi was young, Mia once threw a large porcelain centerpiece at her head. Luckily it missed, but the shattered pieces hit her legs. And I believe my friend'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/may/03/diane-keaton-i-love-woody-allen-i-believe-my-friend|work=The Guardian|date=May 3, 2014}} as well as [[Javier Bardem]], [[Alec Baldwin]], and Keaton again in January 2018.https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/04/javier-bardem-woody-allen{{cite news|last1=Chuba|first1=Kirsten|title=Alec Baldwin Criticizes Stars Denouncing Woody Allen: ‘It’s Unfair and Sad’|url=https://variety.com/2018/biz/news/alec-baldwin-stars-denouncing-woody-allen-unfair-and-sad-1202665291/|work=Variety|date=January 16, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/diane-keaton-defends-woody-allen-sexual-abuse-1202680654/|title=Diane Keaton Defends Woody Allen: ‘I Continue to Believe Him’|last=Fernandez|first=Matt|date=2018-01-29|work=Variety|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en-US}} [[Robert B. Weide]], who made a documentary film on Allen,{{Citation|last=Weide|first=Robert B.|title=Woody Allen: A Documentary|date=2011-11-20|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1895299/|others=Woody Allen, Letty Aronson, Marshall Brickman|accessdate=2018-03-08}} published his rebuttals to the Farrow allegations in an article ''The Woody Allen Allegations: Not So Fast''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/01/27/the-woody-allen-allegations-not-so-fast|title=The Woody Allen Allegations: Not So Fast|last=Weide|first=Robert B.|date=2014-01-27|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en}} [[Cherry Jones]], addressing the topic, said, "There are those who are comfortable in their certainty. I am not. I don't know the truth ... When we condemn by instinct our democracy is on a slippery slope."{{cite news|last1=Ryzik|first1=Melena|last2=Barnes|first2=Brooks|title=Can Woody Allen Work in Hollywood Again?|url= https://nyti.ms/2Fovqcm |work=The New York Times|date=January 28, 2018}} [[Emily Mortimer]], when asked about Allen in an interview, said "I believe in [[due process]]...I think these things really need to go through all the legal processes before anyone can judge. I don’t really have an answer to those questions."Macnab,Geoffrey. (February 19, 2018) [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/emily-mortimer-interview-the-bookshop-woody-allen-mary-poppins-returns-jane-banks-disney-john-a8217661.html "Emily Mortimer Interview"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. Retrieved March 16, 2018. [[Jeff Daniels]], when asked if he would work with Allen again, responded: "I believe Dylan Farrow. Would I do another one with Woody? The difficult decision would be to turn him down, because of ''[[The Purple Rose of Cairo]]''."{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2018/02/jeff-daniels-woody-allen-difficult-decision-1201933381/|title=Jeff Daniels Believes Dylan Farrow But Says Turning Down Woody Allen Would be a ‘Difficult Decision’|website=[[Indiewire.com]]|first=Zack|last=Sharf|date=February 27, 2018|accessdate=March 1, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://people.com/movies/jeff-daniels-woody-allens-legacy-big-asterisk-would-consider-working-with-him/|title=Jeff Daniels Says Woody Allen's Legacy Now Has a 'Big Asterisk'|website=[[People (magazine)|People]]|first=Mike|last=Miller|date=March 9, 2018|accessdate=March 10, 2018}} In February 2018, Savanah Lyon, a theater major at the [[University of California, San Diego]], began organising an online petition to have a course teaching Allen's films removed from the UCSD syllabus. Lyon stated that because of the abuse allegations against him, the university should not have a class devoted to studying Allen's work. On February 16th, the UCSD Academic Senate announced that they were going to retain the course on Allen's work, stating that the removal of courses featuring "controversial material, or even material widely regarded as morally problematic" would undermine the values of free inquiry and [[academic freedom]].Flaherty, Collen.(February 26th, 2018.[https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2018/02/26/uc-san-diego-academic-senate-rejects-student-led-push-cut-course-woody-allen "Woody Allen and Academic Freedom"].Retrieved 3 April 2018. [[Cate Blanchett]], when asked about the allegations against Allen by [[Christiane Amanpour]], replied "At the time, I said it’s a very painful and complicated situation for the family, which I hope they have the ability to resolve." Blanchett added: "If these allegations need to be re-examined which, in my understanding, they’ve been through court, then I’m a big believer in the justice system and setting legal precedents,....If the case needs to be reopened, I am absolutely, wholeheartedly in support of that."Telegraph Reporters, (22 March, 2018).[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2018/03/23/cate-blanchett-denies-staying-silent-metoo-working-woody-allen/ "Cate Blanchett denies 'staying silent' on #MeToo while working with Woody Allen".] ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 3 April 2018. [[Javier Bardem]] stated: "I am very shocked by this sudden treatment. Judgements in the states of New York and Connecticut found him innocent. The legal situation today is the same as in 2007. If there was evidence Woody Allen was guilty, then yes, I would have stopped working with him, but I have doubts."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/apr/19/javier-bardem-defends-woody-allen-i-am-very-shocked-by-this-treatment|title=Javier Bardem defends Woody Allen: 'I am very shocked by this treatment'|website=[[The Guardian]]|first=Guardian|last=Staff|date=April 19, 2018|accessdate=November 9, 2018}} Bardem in another interview stated: "“If the legal situation ever changes [regarding Allen], then I’d change my mind. But for now I don’t agree with the public lynching that he’s been receiving, and if Woody Allen called me to work with him again, I’d be there tomorrow morning. He’s a genius.”{{cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/10/javier-bardem-woody-allen-opinion|title=Javier Bardem Calls Woody Allen Backlash a “Public Lynching”|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|first=Yohanna|last=Desta|date=October 19, 2018|accessdate=November 9, 2018}} [[Penélope Cruz]] stated: "“The only answer that I can give you with common sense that is not about a headline is, the case has to be looked at again, “The important thing is, if there is a case anywhere in the world that isn’t clear, then why not look at it again? I am in favor of that.”{{cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/06/penelope-cruz-woody-allen-dylan-farrow-javier-bardem|title=Penélope Cruz on Woody Allen: “The Case Has to Be Looked at Again”|website=Vanity Fair|first=Paul|last=Chi|date=June 4, 2018|accessdate=October 19, 2018}} Moses Farrow wrote an extensive blog post accusing Mia Farrow of emotionally abusing her children and driving some to suicide: "Most media sources claim my sister Tam died of 'heart failure' at the age of 21. In fact, Tam struggled with depression for much of her life, a situation exacerbated by my mother refusing to get her help, insisting that Tam was just 'moody.' One afternoon in 2000, after one final fight with Mia, which ended with my mother leaving the house, Tam committed suicide by overdosing on pills."{{cite web|url= https://www.mamamia.com.au/moses-mia-farrow-children-woody-allen/|title='There was a darkness within our family.' The complex and tragic story of Mia Farrow’s 14 children|first=Clare|last=Stephens|publisher=[[Mamamia (website)|Mamamia]]|location=Australia|date=May 28, 2018|accessdate=June 9, 2018|archivedate=May 28, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180528141514/https://www.mamamia.com.au/moses-mia-farrow-children-woody-allen/ |deadurl=no}} His sister Soon-Yi had written similarly in 1992, saying in a statement, "Mia was always very hot-tempered and given to rages which terrified all the kids. They can't speak freely because they're still dependent on her. But they could really tell stories and I'm sure one day will. It's true Mia was violent with me and I have conclusive proof, but I hope she and Woody can somehow head off a custody trial."{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/soon-yi-speaks-lets-not-get-hysterical-197958| title=Soon-Yi Speaks: 'Let's Not Get Hysterical'|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=August 30, 1992|accessdate=June 9, 2018| archivedate=April 13, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413120034/http://www.newsweek.com/soon-yi-speaks-lets-not-get-hysterical-197958|deadurl=no}} {{clear}} ==Notes== {{notelist|26em}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite news|last1=Hoban|first1=Phoebe|title=Woody and Mia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3uQCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA40|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=September 21, 1992|pages=32-42}} * [https://www.nytimes.com/1993/05/04/nyregion/doctor-cites-inconsistencies-in-dylan-farrow-s-statements.html Doctor Cites Inconsistencies In Dylan Farrow's Statements], The New York Times, May 4, 1993 * [http://articles.latimes.com/1993-02-02/news/mn-952_1_woody-allen Nanny Casts Doubt on Farrow Charges : Custody: She tells Allen's lawyers the actress pressured her to support molestation accusations against him.
